information: According to the 338Canada statistical model, the Liberal Party is projected to win between 188 and 196 seats. National polling data indicates Liberal support is at 40-45%, compared to 37-38% for the Conservative Party. Polls also show strong performance for the Liberals in Ontario and Quebec, which together account for 199 of the 338 seats in Parliament.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 6 months; the election is expected Oct 20, 2025, with results known that night.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — the Liberals finish below 172 seats (Conservatives lead nationally and in seat projections).
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Conservatives maintain a sizable national lead through the campaign; Bloc holds or grows in Quebec; NDP retains urban/young vote. Result: CPC plurality/majority, Liberals roughly 110–160 seats.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: A sharp late-cycle realignment: Liberals change leader or see a major popularity surge; Conservatives stumble badly during the writ; strategic anti-CPC voting consolidates behind Liberals in Ontario and urban/suburban ridings; Bloc vote softens in Quebec. Result: Liberals sweep Ontario, do very well in Quebec and Atlantic, and edge into 172–185 seats.
forecast.rationale: Baseline conditions point away from a Liberal majority. Through 2023–2024, national polling and seat models consistently had the Conservatives well ahead and the Liberals well below their 2021 level (160 seats). To reach 172+, the Liberals would need material gains over 2021, particularly large margins in Ontario plus strong results in Quebec—despite Bloc and NDP competition—while reversing government-fatigue dynamics. That requires a substantial and sustained opinion shift. The research assistant reports 338Canada projecting 188–196 Liberal seats with Liberals at 40–45% nationally. That is sharply at odds with the longer-run polling trend and my prior knowledge up to late 2024 (CPC leading decisively). Given how slowly national vote intentions typically move and the rarity of an incumbent government rebounding from a deep deficit to a majority in six months, I heavily discount that report without corroboration. Why not higher? Multiple headwinds: incumbent fatigue, cost-of-living concerns, and vote-splitting constraints (Bloc in Quebec; NDP in urban cores) make a Liberal path to 172 narrow. Why not lower? Canadian campaigns can move fast; a leadership change (e.g., to a broadly appealing figure) or a consequential CPC error could catalyze strategic consolidation similar to 2015 dynamics. What would move me up: credible, repeated national polls showing Liberals ≥36–38% with a double-digit Ontario lead, narrowing or reversing CPC lead nationally; Quebec data showing Bloc erosion and Liberal gains; leader net favorables turning positive for the Liberal leader; reputable seat models (338Canada, CBC Poll Tracker) showing a Liberal majority probability ≥30%. What would move me down: persistence of a CPC national lead >8 points into late summer; Ontario polling with CPC tied or ahead; Bloc resilience ≥30% in Quebec; NDP holding ≥18–20% nationally; models assigning near-zero Liberal majority odds.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the Liberal Party win 172 or more seats in the 2025 Canadian federal election?

Question background:
[338Canada Federal Projection](https://338canada.com/federal.htm): "The 338Canada project is a statistical model of electoral projections based on opinion polls, electoral history, and demographic data. This web site is a creation of Philippe J. Fournier, physics and astrophysics professor at Cégep de Saint-Laurent in Montreal."


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the Liberal Party of Canada wins greater than or equal to 172 seats in the [2025 Canadian federal election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Canadian_federal_election).




Your research assistant's report says:
According to the 338Canada statistical model, the Liberal Party is projected to win between 188 and 196 seats. National polling data indicates Liberal support is at 40-45%, compared to 37-38% for the Conservative Party. Polls also show strong performance for the Liberals in Ontario and Quebec, which together account for 199 of the 338 seats in Parliament.

Today is 2025-04-21.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
